column1: @_martinthoma the beauty of CSRF and what sets it apart from other bug classes in my opinion is the fact that it can be used to attack web sites to which the attacker doesn‚Äôt even have access. So isolation - which solves essentially all other security issues - does not help.

CVE-2021-24085 is about a user w/ the ‚ÄúExchange Server Certificates‚Äú role that can access the root cert w/ private key and generate CSRF tokens. Those tokens can be used to trigger a CSRF attack that could lead to an account takeover and the vector could be delivered via email.

column1: There is still SO MUCH CSRF to find in bounty programs.  CSRF comes in many forms. Try:  - Removing the token parameter entirely - Setting the token to a blank string - Changing the token to an invalid token of the same format - Using a different user's token  More in thread üëá

column2: the realistic (I‚Äôm not burning an 0-day) threat of QR codes is mostly CSRF related.  A QR CSRF exploit can only be effective if many people are logged in to a popular service that is vulnerable to CSRF (tiny attack surface).

column1: The script keeps web requests to a bare minimum. One request to grab the CSRF token
column2: then one additional request each time you click a part. Part data is cached until you hit refresh
column3: even if you navigate between result pages.

column1: The reason this works is because TM (& GM) scripts can make exclusions to the cross-origin security policy
column2: in order to pull the CSRF token from the LCSC webpage and then make API requests to their servers.

column1: (3/n)  6. Lack of Brute-Force Protection: Possible to brute-force any length 2FA Code.  7. Missing 2FA Code Integrity Validation: Code for any user acc can be used to bypass the 2FA 8. CSRF on 2FA Disabling: No CSRF Protection on disabling 2FA
